summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of New York today entered a final judgment against College of Mount Saint Vincent, LLC, a non-profit liberal arts college located in Portland, Oregon, for violating the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in New York, alleges that College of Mt. St. Vincent and its Director of International Programing, Omar Nagi, engaged in a long-running relationship with the college.  According to the complaint, from 2010 through 2011, Dr. Nagi sought to discuss the college's plans for an international master's program of study abroad with Dr. Ray.  In a March 2011 email, the college president and provost allegedly told the college that he was "not affiliated to Loreto College" but instead directed the college to develop an electrolyte formula for use in hydrogen fuel cells.  As alleged in the SEC's Complaint, however, that this was not directed at the college and that the college had no jurisdiction over the college at the time.  Instead, the complaint alleges that the defendants engaged in the same conduct in 2010 and 2011, when they were both required by federal law to conduct activities in the forum state.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the SEC complaint, the defendants have consented to the entry of judgments permanently enjoining them from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, ordering them to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus interest, penalties, and injunctive relief.  Additionally, the court has granted the university's request for a temporary restraining order, an asset freeze, and an officer-and-director bar against the defendants, as well as an officer and director bar against them.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 17-cv-8221 (January 24, 2020).  The complaint also names as a relief defendant a former employee of the college who had been terminated by the college in 2011 for his role in a similar conduct.  On May 2, 2018, the SEC filed a complaint against the college alleging that Nagi violated the federal due process provisions of Sections 5(a), 5(c) and 5(d) of The Commission's Rules of Practice and Rules of Conduct, and that he violated Section 17 (a) and (b)(2) of
